title: Ropsten sync issues / discussion
body:
Hi Tomasz,

im trying to run the Runner from within visual studio 2017. Im getting this error message:
_2018-11-06 09:41:48.7958|ERROR|1|Runner.Program|Failure|Config file does not exist configs\ropsten_windows_discovery.config.json_

Are the discovery files missing from the repo?

Thanks,
Anders.

Hi Anders,

Thanks for reporting this. We changed the ropsten config file name to ropsten_windows.config.json (when running on windows) and ropsten_posix.config.son (when running on Mac or Linux). We have not updated VS project files references since we have all switched to Rider for development.

I will review the VS project files and write a Wiki where I will describe how to launch all the different testnets. This will be tracked in this issue and I will paste a link here.

Since it is on our priority list anyway I expect it to be available here by Friday, possibly tonight.
In the meantime you can change it in the project run config in VS.

A link for reference until we fix it:
https://social.msdn.microsoft.com/Forums/vstudio/en-US/41b3ab99-ddc7-45d7-9196-86a3b2dc5516/how-to-pass-arguments-to-a-console-app-through-visual-studio-debugging-scenario?forum=csharpgeneral

Thanks Tomasz, its running now on Ropsten:
2018-11-06 14:31:56.5617|INFO|4|Runner.Runners.JsonRpcRunner|Running server, url: http://127.0.0.1:8555|

I can't see it syncing the blockchain though? I can also wait for the wiki entry you mentioned .)

It should go further, are you running on Windows?

Running server, url: http://127.0.0.1:8545|

It may take a while before it finds first nodes to sync with (although for me it took under a minute)

I will keep looking for some quality documentation format. Ropsten sync should run after you aunch it like here:
https://github.com/NethermindEth/nethermind/wiki/Ropsten-Sync

It seems to stop at "Connected to 1 bootnodes, ..."

Will it notify me if some ports are not open?

Here are the full output:

Running with the debugger I got this exception now:

```
System.IO.InvalidDataException
  HResult=0x80131501
  Message=Input is not a valid snappy-compressed block
  Source=Snappy.Standard
  StackTrace:
   at Snappy.SnappyCodec.Uncompress(Byte[] input, Int32 offset, Int32 length, Byte[] output, Int32 outOffset)
   at Snappy.SnappyCodec.Uncompress(Byte[] input)
   at Nethermind.Network.Rlpx.SnappyDecoder.Decode(IChannelHandlerContext context, Packet message, List`1 output) in ---\Repos\nethermind\src\Nethermind\Nethermind.Network\Rlpx\SnappyDecoder.cs:line 54
   at DotNetty.Codecs.MessageToMessageDecoder`1.ChannelRead(IChannelHandlerContext context, Object message)
```

This exception is thrown but handled and treated as non-critical and logged on the debug level. It suggests a compression algorithm / protocol mismatch between us and some nodes. Most likely these are some rogue nodes that are not following the rules properly and can be ignored since Parity and Geth communicate with us all fine.
Is my guess correct that the exception is shown in green in Visual Studio and not yellow? You can switch the settings in visual studio not to stop on user handled exception.

For Ropsten hanging on Connected to 1 bootnodes
(1) it may take a while before finding the nodes to sync - did you wait with the app running for 5 / 10 minutes? (just in case there is some big struggle to find a valid node
(2) there is a log file in the [NethermindDIr]/logs which may contain any exception if they happened

Interesting to know about the protocol mismatch from some nodes. Im hitting several different exceptions (User-Unhandled) regarding sync data.

For instance:
```
System.NullReferenceException
  HResult=0x80004003
  Message=Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
  Source=Nethermind.Network
  StackTrace:
   at Nethermind.Network.Rlpx.NettyHandshakeHandler.ChannelActive(IChannelHandlerContext context) in ..Repos\nethermind\src\Nethermind\Nethermind.Network\Rlpx\NettyHandshakeHandler.cs:line 79
   at DotNetty.Transport.Channels.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.InvokeChannelActive()
```
Its the Channel object that is null:
`
            _p2PSession.RemoteHost = ((IPEndPoint)context.Channel.RemoteAddress).Address.ToString();`

However, the syncing is continuing which is good.

Thanks.

@vindberg there are various different geth forks that people were running to support various ICO projects they were building - due to discovery protocol limitations often you cannot discard them before you start P2P conversation and there you may have protocol mismatch
Obviously it may be still an issue around how we handle snappy serialization and we plan to create a list of nodes that are causing this issue to occur and review whether these are in fact some random unfinished implementations / old buggy versions.

Object reference issue on channel is happening with a race conditions when two nodes are disconnecting but there are still messages being delivered. We would like to fix this but assigned to it lower priority since it happens when the nodes already decide to disconnect (this is or intuition so far). 

How is your sync progress on Ropsten?

Thanks again.

Running on my local machine directly from Visual Studio it was syncing just fine and had received 1GB+ of data when I shut it down (taking too much resources).

Now I have put it on a VM on Azure (Windows 10) and getting this error (from logs.txt):
Command: 
`dotnet Nethermind.Runner.dll --config configs/ropsten_windows.config.json --baseDbPath C:\Ethereum\Storage`
```
2018-11-07 10:01:37.9345|ERROR|1|Runner.Program|Failure System.TypeInitializationException: The type initializer for 'Nethermind.Runner.RunnerApp' threw an exception. ---> System.TypeInitializationException: The type initializer for 'Nethermind.Secp256k1.Proxy' threw an exception. ---> System.DllNotFoundException: Unable to load DLL 'secp256k1.dll' or one of its dependencies: The specified module could not be found. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x8007007E)
   at Nethermind.Secp256k1.Proxy.Win64Lib.secp256k1_context_create(UInt32 flags)
   at Nethermind.Secp256k1.Proxy.CreateContext() in C:\src\nethermind\src\Nethermind\Nethermind.Secp256k1\Proxy.cs:line 208
   at Nethermind.Secp256k1.Proxy..cctor() in C:\src\nethermind\src\Nethermind\Nethermind.Secp256k1\Proxy.cs:line 182
   --- End of inner exception stack trace ---
   at Nethermind.Secp256k1.Proxy.VerifyPrivateKey(Byte[] privateKey) in C:\src\nethermind\src\Nethermind\Nethermind.Secp256k1\Proxy.cs:line 220
   at Nethermind.Core.Crypto.PrivateKey..ctor(Byte[] keyBytes) in C:\src\nethermind\src\Nethermind\Nethermind.Core\Crypto\PrivateKey.cs:line 41
   at Nethermind.Runner.RunnerApp..cctor() in C:\src\nethermind\src\Nethermind\Nethermind.Runner\RunnerApp.cs:line 39
   --- End of inner exception stack trace ---
   at Nethermind.Runner.RunnerApp..ctor(ILogger logger) in C:\src\nethermind\src\Nethermind\Nethermind.Runner\RunnerApp.cs:line 43
   at Nethermind.Runner.Program.Main(String[] args) in C:\src\nethermind\src\Nethermind\Nethermind.Runner\Program.cs:line 43
```

One of the three:
(1) you are running it on 32bit machine - Nethermind only runs on 64bit architectures
(2) some dependency is missing and you can track it by using this application on secp256k1.dll:
https://github.com/lucasg/Dependencies
(3) there is no secp256k1.dll in your Runner bin folder if VS failed to copy content properly (you can find it in the repo and copy to bin manually)

One of two things worked:

1. I installed https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/2977003/the-latest-supported-visual-c-downloads
2. I copied the secp256k1.dll from the External folder into the executing folder (and override the original dll)

Syncing now üëç
Thanks, added the C++ redistributable info to readme. Also I just managed to fix the consensus issue on Rinkeby so there is a chance that the latest master has a syncing Rinkeby that you can try.

Great.
Its at just about 110 GB in storage now, still running good. Are there any interface or dashboard of sorts for the node? Im sorry if I missed this feature in any documentation.

Best,
Anders

Hi Anders,

If you are running the latest master then you can use JSON RPC (most of the methods supported by geth would work).

To make Nethermind run with JSON RPC you need to open the configuration file (configs/ropsten_windows.config.json) and set "JsonRpcEnabled": true and then set HttpHost and HttpPort. HttpHost - you can set it to 127.0.0.1 for local connections, internal or external IP depending on where you want to connect from. The node needs to be restarted after configuration changes.

You can look at the JSON RPC spec below - let us know if any methods that are missing would be important for you:
https://github.com/ethereum/wiki/wiki/JSON-RPC

Best,
Tomasz

The JSON RPC is enabled and im gonna try using it for a small dapp im building.

I was thinking of a GUI for the node showing connected peers, settings, sync level etc. and general node health.

Its online now: http://validators-ropsten-1.westeurope.cloudapp.azure.com:8555/

Thanks again Tomasz.

OK, I guess the list of peers would be missing now so we will need to cover that. 
I guess you will need:
 * net_peerCount
 * eth_syncing
 * net_istening

Track it in #227 and add any comments there. I guess this should be ready by the end of Monday

http://validators-ropsten-1.westeurope.cloudapp.azure.com:8555/
will try to connect next time it is up
